oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Slave and business office at Clifton Place
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Detail of the slave and business office showing the west elevation of Clifton Place.

Clifton Place, named after the Clifton Turnpike, was the antebellum home of General Gideon J. Pillow (1806-1877). The original Greek Revival style home was built by Nathan Vaught in 1838, and the home had several later additions. During the Civil War, it was confiscated by the Federal government, but it was returned to General Pillow after the war. The office on the property was originally served as a plantation and slave office.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Eason, W. Jeter
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Dwellings--Tennessee; Architecture, Domestic--Tennessee; Greek revival (Architecture); Clifton Place Plantation (Maury County, Tenn.); Plantations--Tennessee
